title: Seared Branzino with Couscous
description: Crisp-skinned seared branzino served over fluffy lemon-herb couscous with a bright parsley-caper vinaigrette. Simple pan-searing develops golden flavor while light, fragrant couscous soaks up citrus and olive oil for a Mediterranean-style weeknight dinner.

ingredients.display_name: whole branzino, scaled and gutted (about 8-10 oz each)
ingredients.notes: rinse and pat dry; leave head on or remove per preference; score skin 2-3 shallow slashes per side

ingredients.display_name: low-sodium chicken broth (or vegetable broth for pescatarian)

ingredients.notes: used for deglazing; may substitute additional broth

steps.text: Prep ingredients: rinse and pat the branzino dry, score the skin, season inside cavity and both sides with half the salt and pepper; measure and chop parsley, zest and juice lemons, rinse capers, and bring broth to a simmer.

Cook couscous: bring hot broth, 1 tbsp olive oil and 1 tbsp butter to a simmer in a medium saucepan; stir in couscous, cover, remove from heat and let steam until liquid is absorbed; fluff with a fork and stir in lemon zest, half the lemon juice, chopped parsley, capers, a pinch of salt and remaining olive oil.
Heat a large heavy skillet (preferably cast iron) over medium-high heat until very hot; add remaining 2 tbsp olive oil and 1 tbsp butter and swirl to coat.

Sear fish: place branzino skin-side down in the hot pan and press gently to ensure even contact; cook undisturbed until skin is deeply golden and releases easily from the pan, about 3-4 minutes depending on thickness.

Flip fish carefully and add minced garlic and optional white wine to the pan to deglaze; spoon pan juices over the fish and cook until fish is just cooked through and flakes easily, about 2-3 minutes.

Finish sauce: remove fish to a warm plate; reduce heat to low, add remaining butter, remaining lemon juice, red pepper flakes if using and any accumulated juices, swirl to emulsify a quick vinaigrette-like sauce, then spoon over fish.
Plate: divide couscous among plates, top with seared branzino, spoon lemon-caper sauce over, garnish with additional parsley and lemon wedges, and serve immediately.
